content: To use mailwasher you have to use POP. You say your checked SPAM, did you check it on your providers website/webmail? POP rarely downloads mail providers consider SPAM, they usually sequester it server side folders and do not offer it to POP for download.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: you reference PGP, Thunderbird does not use PGP as Linux users understand it, it maintains it's own key database. See https://support.mozilla.org/kb/introduction-to-e2e-encryption#w_how-to-use-openpgp-end-to-end-encryption-with-thunderbird
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
They are stored in the folder defined in account settings > composition and storage for sent mail.

Try right clicking the message and selecting open > open message in conversation to see a threaded view with the reply included.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
In Folder Pane. the accounts 'Sent' folder should store sent emails. That 'Sent' folder may be called 'Sent Mail' or 'Sent Items' etc If a pop account it will be called 'Sent'. If an imap account it usually uses whatever is the name used by the server eg: 'Sent' or 'Sent Mail' or 'Sent Items' etc

In Account Settings Select 'Copies & Folders' for the account Typically the following is selected:

Select checkbox: 'Place a copy in' If pop account select 'Sent folder on' and choose same pop account. If imap account select 'Other' and choose eg: 'Sent on pop account name'

content:
that part of the message is weird. That looks? like an IPV6 internet address which is "unknown" in DNS in so much as it has no name "unknown". But it is the port that is truly weird. 51018

The IP address appears to resolve to a city of Ville in France. But I have no idea what could be using Port 51018 as it is not assigned to any "normal" protocol. It is a dynamic port that I would guess could be used for a VPN internally, or a proxy in a public wifi situation.

My guess is you are trying to send mail from an IP address your service provider does not allow for that purpose.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: It needs to appear 'local' to Thunderbird. You can easily test this by - exiting thunerbird - copying the imapmail\<account> to your cloud folder that has a drive allocation - start thunderbird, click account settings and on 'serversettings' pane, change the link to account folder to the cloud folder - thunderbird will close and restart. check and see if all is ok . if so, you can remove the folder on hard drive.

content:
The people who answer questions here, for the most part, are other users volunteering their time (like me), not Mozilla employees or developers. This means we have no access to your system to check anything, we can only work with you to help you fix your own problem based on the information you provide. Details of mail provider and the exact messages you see raised by the software are critical for this process to succeed.

If you want to leave feedback for developers, you can go to the Firefox Help menu and select Share ideas and feedback…. Alternatively, you can use this link. Your feedback gets collected by a team of people who read it and gather data about the most common issues.

You can also file a bug report or feature request. See File a bug report or feature request for Mozilla products for details.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
The easiest way is to copy the entire profile. Those steps are here:

BACKUP from old PC

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE to new PC

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there

BUT From your post, it appears you are using an older version. Is the version on new PC the same? If not, the safest conversion would be to install the same version on new PC. That would ensure total compatibility.

ALTERNATE APPROACH

Okay, if you don't want to do that, and just import the message folders, you can do this: - exit thunderbird - in windows file explorer, locate the Local Folders folder of old profile and copy the message folders (but not the msf files) to the Local Folders folder on new PC - if the account is POP, the account needs to have already been installed on new PC. Copying the message folders will overlay any messages you have already downloaded. If that isn't an issue, locate the Mail\<accountname> folder on old PC and copy everything there to same location on new PC.
creator: davidsk

content: These steps usually work: - create an entry in the thunderbird addressbook with all the fields you want - export the thunderbook as csv -this is just to provide a good template - load into a spreadsheet to verify the first row - now, open your outlook csv into a separate spreadsheet and adjust to mimic the template So far, that series of steps work
